question: what sarah her cheif complaint and what diagnostic testing was carried out?

context_metadata.chunk:
Medical History Report  
Patient Information:  
• Name: Sarah Johnson  
• Date of Birth:  June 22, 1975  
• Gender: Female  
• Marital Status:  Single  
• Occupation:  Teacher  
• Primary Care Physician:  Dr. Michael Brown  
Chief Complaint:  
• Severe headaches and dizziness for the past month. History of Present Illness:  
• Onset: Symptoms began approximately 30 days ago. • Duration:  Symptoms occur daily, lasting several hours. • Character:  The headache is described as throbbing, primarily located on the right side 
of the head, often accompanied by dizziness and nausea. • Associated Symptoms:  Light sensitivity, occasional vomiting, and blurred vision. • Aggravating Factors:  Stress, loud noises, and bright lights. • Relieving Factors:  Resting in a dark, quiet room, over -the-counter pain relief. • Previous Episodes:  Similar episodes occurred intermittently over the past year but have 
become more frequent and severe. Past Medical History:  
• Migraines:  Diagnosed in 2014, managed with lifestyle modifications and over -the-
counter medications. • Seasonal Allergies:  Managed with antihistamines as needed. • Surgeries:  Cholecystectomy in 2012. • Chronic Conditions:  None reported. Family History:  
• Father: Alive, age 75 (hypertension, hyperlipidemia). • Mother: Deceased at age 68 (breast cancer). • Siblings:  One sister (age 45, history of migraines).

• Cardiovascular:  Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. • Respiratory:  Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. • Abdomen:  Soft, non -tender, no hepatosplenomegaly. • Extremities:  No cyanosis, clubbing, or edema. • Neurological:  Cranial nerves II -XII intact, no focal deficits. Assessment:  
• Recurrent severe headaches and dizziness, likely migraines with aura. Differential 
diagnosis includes:  
o Migraine headaches  
o Tension-type headaches  
o Vestibular migraine  
o Secondary causes (e.g., intracranial mass, vascular malformation)  
Plan:  
1. Diagnostic Testing:  
o MRI of the brain to rule out secondary causes. o Complete metabolic panel (CMP) and complete blood count (CBC) to assess 
overall health. 2. Medications:  
o Sumatriptan 50 mg: One tablet at the onset of headache, may repeat once after 
2 hours if needed. o Propranolol 20 mg: One tablet twice daily as a prophylactic measure. 3. Follow-Up:  
o Schedule follow -up appointment in four weeks to evaluate response to 
treatment and review MRI results. 4. Patient Education:  
o Advise on the importance of maintaining a headache diary to identify potential 
triggers. o Educate about lifestyle modifications including regular sleep patterns, stress 
management techniques, and dietary considerations.

• Alcohol:  Consumes alcohol occasionally, 1 -2 drinks per month. • Drug Use:  Denies any recreational drug use. • Exercise:  Regular yoga and walking. • Diet: Balanced diet, includes fruits, vegetables, and lean proteins. Review of Systems:  
• General:  Reports fatigue, denies weight loss or night sweats. • Skin: No rashes or lesions. • Head, Eyes, Ears, Nose, Throat (HEENT):  Denies hearing loss, sore throat, or nasal 
congestion. • Cardiovascular:  Denies chest pain, palpitations, or edema. • Respiratory:  Denies cough, shortness of breath, or wheezing. • Gastrointestinal:  Occasional nausea and vomiting related to headaches, denies other 
gastrointestinal symptoms. • Genitourinary:  Denies dysuria, hematuria, or frequency. • Musculoskeletal:  Denies joint pain, swelling, or stiffness. • Neurological:  Reports headaches, dizziness, and blurred vision; denies weakness, 
numbness, or seizures. • Psychiatric:  Denies depression, anxiety, or other psychiatric conditions. Medications:  
• Ibuprofen 400 mg:  As needed for headache relief. • Cetirizine 10 mg:  One tablet daily during allergy season. Physical Examination:  
• Vital Signs:  
o Blood Pressure: 125/78 mmHg  
o Heart Rate: 72 bpm  
o Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths/min  
o Temperature: 98.6°F  
o Oxygen Saturation: 98% on room air  
• General:  Alert, oriented, in mild distress due to headache. • HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic.

Pupils equal, round, reactive to light. Mild 
photophobia noted. No papilledema on fundoscopic exam. • Neck: No jugular venous distension, no lymphadenopathy.
